<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BTM5909</span> - Ethics and global corporate governance<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BTM5909">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-business-law-and-taxation.html">Department of Business Law and Taxation</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Thaatchaayini Kananatu">Dr Thaatchaayini Kananatu</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BTM5909&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BTM5909&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BTM5909">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students must have completed 72 credit points.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is designed to develop postgraduate students' ethical reasoning regarding the behaviour and conduct of international business organisations.</p>
<p>Topics include the extent to which multi-national corporations (MNCs) act ethically, the social responsibilities and obligations of MNCs, and how corporate governance practices ensure accountability, transparency and integrity in managing businesses.</p>
<p>This unit examines these fundamental questions by applying ethical and corporate governance theories to issues that arise in international business organisations. These issues may involve the 17 United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) relating to human rights, environmental protection, marketing and advertising, human resource management and social accounting.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify and examine significant ethical issues that arise in various international business contexts</li>
<li>apply different ethical theories to issues specific to human rights, environmental protection, marketing and advertising, human resource management and social accounting</li>
<li>critically evaluate the implications of applying different ethical theories to international business</li>
<li>identify and examine the role of the various stakeholders in upholding good global corporate governance practices</li>
<li>critically evaluate the impact of regulations and codes in corporate governance in various jurisdictions, especially in developed and developing countries.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Examination: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment, and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning, and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MPH5041</span> - Introductory biostatistics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MPH5041">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-epidemiology-and-preventive-medicine.html">Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andrew Forbes">Prof. Andrew Forbes</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Baki Billah">Dr Baki Billah</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>Enrolment for the DE mode of this unit is quota restricted.
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MPH5041&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MPH5041&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MPH5041">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-alfred-hospital.html">Alfred Hospital</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled one of the following course codes:0046, 0160, 0702, 1884, 2311, 2312, 2314, 2868, 2870, 2872, 3198, 3403, 3416, 3420, 3421, 3422, 3440, 3807, 3862, 3873, 3874, 3896, 3900, M4006, M5007, M5017, M5018, M6008, M6023, M6024, M6025, M6026, M6027, M6028</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MPH6041.html">MPH6041</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Students do not have provision to borrow SPSS CD from Monash University; they have to lease/buy it from IBM SPSS.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit  introduces students to biostatistics as applied to public health and  management studies. Biostatistics is the science of describing, summarising, and analysing health-related data. It is essential to understand biostatistics in order to  design, conduct, and interpret health-related research. The basic principles and methods used in biostatistics are covered in this unit. This includes the technical qualifications necessary for analysing and interpreting data on a descriptive and bivariate level.</p>
<p>Topics include classifying health data; summarising data using simple statistical  methods and  graphical  presentation; sampling distributions; quantifying uncertainty in results from a sample; working with statistical distributions; comparing two or more groups/methods using confidence intervals and hypothesis tests (p - values); assessing the association between an outcome and an exposure using the chi-squared test; using risk comparisons (RR and OR); predicting an event or identifying risk factors for an event of interest where the event is measured on a continuous scale or a binary scale (yes/no).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Classify data into appropriate measurement types.</li>
<li>Present data using relevant tables, graphical displays, and summary statistics, quantify uncertainty in study results.</li>
<li>Formulate research hypotheses into a statistical context in public health studies.</li>
<li>Estimate quantities of interest and evaluate hypothesis with appropriate statistical methods.</li>
<li>Accurately interpret statistical methods and results reported in health publications.</li>
<li>Analyse data using a specific software package.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Structured written report 1 (1500 words) (15%)</li>
<li>Structured written report 2 (2000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Structured written report 3 (2500 words) (45%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Online test (MCQ) (30 minutes) (10%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Sem 1 - DAY mode: 4 face-to-face contact hours (2 hours lecture and 2 hours tutorial) + 2 hours online guided discussion + 6 hours independent study per week.</p>
<p>Sem 1 - DE mode: 24 contact hours over 3 block days + 2 hours online tutorial + 2 hours online guided discussion + 6 hours independent study per week.</p>
<p>Sem 2 - DE mode: 2 hours online lectures (recorded) + 2 hours online tutorial + 2 hours online guided discussion + 6 hours of independent study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>3 day on-campus block for off-campus students.</p>
<p>Note: Semester 2 is only available in off-campus mode and no attendance is required during this Semester</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/public-health">Public health</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/biostatistics">Biostatistics</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/epidemiology/pgrad">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/epidemiology/pgrad</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">VCM4101</span> - Introduction to multimedia imaging<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-VCM4101">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeffrey Janet">Mr Jeffrey Janet</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samuel Berkoh">Mr Samuel Berkoh</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-VCM4101">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to MMM &amp; MMDes course</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces the student to the different aspects of digital imaging for multimedia. The process of creating and using digital imaging effectively is defined and students will gain an understanding of the theory behind the inclusion of digital images in multimedia production. Students undertake project work which explores a range of technical skills and design concepts for incorporating digital images into multimedia production.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the process of converting visual material into a digital format using scanning and image capturing technology;</li>
<li>Understand the types of digital imaging including still graphics, animation and video, 2D and 3D;</li>
<li>Understand the composition of the digital image including resolution and compression formats;</li>
<li>Have the skills to manipulate digital images using digital editing software;</li>
<li>Have the skills to create a digital image using digital editing software;</li>
<li>Be aware of the different digital image formats applicable to different multimedia authoring environments;</li>
<li>Understand the process of inclusion of digital images into multimedia authoring environments.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Individual projects (75%)</p>
<p>Essay 1250 words (25%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including a 1-hour lecture, 2 studio hours and 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5555</span> - Digital tourism economy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5555">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-languages-literatures-cultures-and-linguistics.html">School of Languages, Literatures, Cultures and Linguistics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Isaac Mizrachi">Dr Isaac Mizrachi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Isaac Mizrachi">Dr Isaac Mizrachi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=APG5555&amp;tpCode=T3-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 3</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=APG5555&amp;tpCode=T3-58&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester 3</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5555">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 3 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Trimester 3 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/APG5389.html">APG5389</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on the rise of the digital economy and the impact is having on the tourism and events industries. Topics include: new media and consumer behaviour, social media digital marketing in tourism (such as Instagram and Facebook), virtual reality applications in the industry, new digital business models for small and medium sized enterprises and disruptive innovation, the rise of the sharing economy (such as Airbnb), artificial intelligence and robotics, sensors and internet-of-things. Data science and innovative research methodologies in tourism are studied including website data analytics, digital tracking and pattern recognition in 'big data' to assist market segmentation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse the impact of the digital economy on the tourism industry.</li>
<li>Discuss the contemporary scope of digital technologies and their applicability to the tourism industry.</li>
<li>Explain the implications of digital technologies on the tourism economy for different destinations, events and companies.</li>
<li>Evaluate the applicability of social media marketing techniques as used in the industry.</li>
<li>Utilise "big data" research techniques.</li>
<li>Undertake applied research in the field of digital technologies for small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs).</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/international-sustainable-tourism-management">International sustainable tourism management</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/tourism">Tourism</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BND4082</span> - Improving the population's nutrition<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BND4082">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicole Kellow">Nicole Kellow</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Claire Palermo">Assoc. Prof Claire Palermo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BND4082&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BND4082">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>A student must have passed a minimum of 144 credit points of units deemed satisfactory and relevant in content and depth by the Nutrition and Dietetic Department Selection Officer in conjunction with the Unit Coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BND4092.html">BND4092</a></span> and BND students only.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will be classroom based and develop student's knowledge of the foundations of public health and public health nutrition as a discipline. Students will explore the role of population nutritional intake and its relationship to health and the strategies and approaches at a population level that are effective in improving health, including legislation, policy, social marketing, community development, health education and screening. The focus of content will be on the practical application of the principles, theories and processes used to develop population based approaches to improving health through nutrition, with a focus on capacity building. This unit will prepare students for a practical placement in public health nutrition (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BND4092.html">BND4092</a></span>).</p>
<p>The key theme explored in this unit is Theme 2: Determinants and influences on population health and nutrition coupled with partial integration of content from Theme 4: Food: from science to systems.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the key health and nutrition issues affecting the Australian population and the political, environmental, social and economic determinants of these.</li>
<li>Apply the key steps in the public health nutrition intervention cycle and explain the importance of integrating capacity building within this framework.</li>
<li>Evaluate the role of public health policy in shaping public health nutrition practice.</li>
<li>Analyse the continuum of population based approaches for addressing nutrition issues and evaluate the level of evidence of effectiveness in improving health.</li>
<li>Evaluate a socio-ecological, systems based, approach to understanding and managing population nutrition issues.</li>
<li>Differentiate between effective and non-effective public health advocacy approaches.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Group project proposal (2,000 words equivalent) (30%)</li>
<li>Group oral presentation (20%)</li>
<li>Individual discussion paper (3,000 words equivalent) (50%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Week 1: 3 workshops x 4 hours per day = 12 hours</p>
<p>Week 2-12: 3 hours per week face to face teaching and learning sessions supported by group work and self-directed learning and an additional 12 hours per week of self-study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nutrition">Nutrition</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2410</span> - Narrative<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2410">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-literary-studies.html">Literary Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2410&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2410">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Two gateway units in Literary studies, or permission from the unit coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3410, AZA2410, AZA3410</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit will investigate story-telling, narrative literature and the role of narrative in a range of cultural contexts. What constitutes narrative? What are its primary features? How does story-telling communicate meaning? How do we construct effective narrative texts? What do we do with narrative? What is the future of narrative? The texts studied are drawn from a variety of genres and countries.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successfully completing the unit students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and describe different forms of narrative;</li>
<li>Analyse different narrative genres, devices and techniques;</li>
<li>Apply some of the theoretical perspectives developed in literary and cultural studies disciplines for the critical analysis of narrative;</li>
<li>Identify and account for historical perspectives and conventions within which literature and other narrative texts are produced.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/literary-studies">Literary studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_pha"><span class="unitcode">BPS1011</span> - Human Physiology I: Cells to systems<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BPS1011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_pha">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-pha.html">Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jennifer Short">Dr Jennifer Short</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jennifer Short">Dr Jennifer Short</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BPS1011&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BPS1011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-parkville.html">Parkville</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>PSC1011</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Unit previously coded PSC1011 Physiology I</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit lays a foundation of knowledge about mammalian systems and provides the relationship between pathophysiology and the rational design and use of drugs. Students will be introduced to the physiological basis of disease, highlighting the causal connections between cell biochemistry, body function at the tissue, organ and system level and human health. Several cells, organs and systems will be considered in detail, and one or more examples of disease states which are amenable to pharmacotherapy will be discussed.</p>
<p>The unit aims to provide a basic understanding of the functions of organs and systems such as the nervous and endocrinological systems; however, an equal emphasis will be placed on one of the key components of drug discovery, the choice of therapeutic target based on a thorough understanding of the disease process. The principal aim of this unit is to provide students with an understanding of basic biological principles and how these can be applied in pharmaceutical science.  Students will be introduced to experimental approaches to solving biochemical and physiological research questions and to fundamental laboratory techniques.</p>
<p>Topics to be covered include:</p>
<ul>
<li>cells, tissues, organs and systems</li>
<li>homeostasis</li>
<li>macromolecules</li>
<li>metabolism</li>
<li>DNA replication, gene transcription and translation</li>
<li>the nervous system</li>
<li>endocrinology</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the end of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the role of molecules, cells, tissues, organs and systems in ensuring homeostasis and effective functioning of the body;</li>
<li>Compare different body systems in terms of their structure and function at the organ, tissue, cell and macromolecule level;</li>
<li>Explain how drug molecules target cell components to mimic, modulate or disrupt physiological processes;</li>
<li>Predict the effect of disrupting cellular processes on cellular and system function and on human health;</li>
<li>Suggest a rational drug therapy strategy to target a disease state with known pathophysiological causes;</li>
<li>Design and perform an hypothesis-driven experimental approach to investigate physiological processes;</li>
<li>Safely and effectively carry out a basic practical procedure using common biochemical and physiological techniques;</li>
<li>Analyse and communicate experimental findings;</li>
<li>Research a topic in the area of physiology, and present the findings of such research (written and verbal), at an appropriate scientific level.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Final exam (2 hour):50%; in-semester assessment 50%.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>One hour per week of guided preparation (online)</li>
<li>Two hours per week of interactive lectures</li>
<li>Three hours per week of practicals or workshops</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="https://www.intranet.monash/pharm/students/undergrad/courses/bpharmsci">https://www.intranet.monash/pharm/students/undergrad/courses/bpharmsci</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUT2002</span> - Applied research methods in nutrition<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUT2002">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maxine Bonham">Assoc Prof Maxine Bonham</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Judi Porter">Dr Judi Porter</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUT2002&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUT2002">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1002.html">NUT1002</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1010.html">NUT1010</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1101.html">NUT1101</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT2001.html">NUT2001</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course M2001.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will focus on developing students as researchers. It builds on knowledge and skills developed in Year 1 on the role of evidence in nutrition science, statistics, epidemiology and research methods.It will embrace the concepts and application of systematic literature review and quantitative and qualitative data related to nutrition. Students will be supported to apply and practice these research skills in a safe classroom environment and via hypothetical models while applying real and relevant data collection and analysis tools to current, pertinent and important research questions in nutrition. The key theme explored in this unit is Theme 2: Determinants and Influences on Population Health and Nutrition coupled with partial integration of content and application from Theme 1: Personal Development and Professional Practice and Theme 3: Nutrition Fundamentals of Health and Disease.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically appraise scientific literature and research methods;</li>
<li>Conduct a hypothetical research study relating to a nutrition issue;</li>
<li>Apply methods of qualitative and quantitative data collection, analysis and communication in controlled environment;</li>
<li>Develop and implement a systematic review protocol for a nutrition related research question;</li>
<li>Synthesise and communicate findings from scientific literature in the field of nutrition.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Group systematic literature review (4,000 words) (50%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Individual scientific report (4,000 - 5,000 words) (50%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Assessment task ethics forms (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours contact per week lectures/tutorials/teaching sessions on campus.</p>
<p>9 hours self study and assessment related work.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nutrition">Nutrition</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2004</span> - Chinese intermediate 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2004">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-chinese-studies.html">Chinese Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Gloria Davies">Professor Gloria Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Gloria Davies">Professor Gloria Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2004&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2004&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2004">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-overseas.html">Overseas</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2003.html">ATS2003</a></span> or equivalent/permission</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2024, ATS3024</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>If this is your language entry point, this unit requires a <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">language entry level test</a><span class="hbk-print-url">language entry level test (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Chinese Intermediate 2 completes an overview of the important sentence structures of modern standard Chinese.  Equal emphasis is placed on the four skills of reading, writing, listening and speaking.  Speaking classes cover practical, everyday situations to develop interactive competence at a basic level in a range of situations likely to be encountered in daily life in contemporary China.  In addition to regular classroom activities, listening and reading skills will be further developed through the use of audio/visual, Web-based and computer assisted learning materials.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Building on the language skills acquired in Chinese Intermediate 1, upon successful completion of Chinese Intermediate 2 students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>read and write around an additional 200 Chinese characters (900) total.</li>
<li>critically reflect on the basic syntax system of Modern Standard Chinese and on the similarities and differences between it and English.</li>
<li>employ a grammatical framework to analyse and describe the vernacular Chinese under study facilitating progression to later study of formal written Chinese (in Chinese Online Media and Advanced Chinese).</li>
<li>orally communicate quantitatively and qualitatively using appropriate levels of formality in a range of everyday, practical situations.</li>
<li>read simple modern vernacular texts.</li>
<li>demonstrate language proficiency equivalent to Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) level A2.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Exam: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/chinese-studies">Chinese studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS1287</span> - Performance in context 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS1287">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-centre-for-theatre-and-performance.html">Centre for Theatre and Performance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Felix Nobis">Dr Felix Nobis</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Felix Nobis">Dr Felix Nobis</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS1287&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS1287">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>DTS1060</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Performance in Context I will be a foundational unit in the Theatre major and minor. Whilst offering a general introduction to concepts, theories and practices in the discipline, the primary focus of the unit will be on theatre history and historiography. Students will examine the development of theatrical conventions in key periods of theatre history, and the relationship of theatrical performance to social, political and cultural forces. The continuing influence of past modes of performance in the development of contemporary theatrical forms will also be explored.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Students successfully completing this unit will develop:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Familiarity with concepts, theories and practices within the discipline Theatre Studies</li>
<li>Deeper knowledge of theatre history</li>
<li>Ability to perform research in theatre history</li>
<li>Understanding of the ways in which performance codes of historicized texts might be translated into the processes of contemporary theatre</li>
<li>Awareness of the range of communicative languages used on stage, and of the critical discourses appropriate to their description and analysis</li>
<li>Ability to articulate critical interpretations of dramatic texts and processes in systematic written argument.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/theatre-and-performance">Theatre and performance</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">AHT2712</span> - Curating: Histories and theories<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AHT2712">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-fine-art.html">Department of Fine Art</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Luke Morgan">Associate Professor Luke Morgan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tara McDowell">Associate Professor Tara McDowell</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AHT2712&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AHT2712">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>12 credit points at first year level in Art History &amp; Theory, or Theory of Art &amp; Design, or Visual Culture, or permission from the Unit Coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AHT3712.html">AHT3712</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will offer students an introduction to the most important and influential theories of curating and provide an overview of the history of curating from the mid-18th century on. Although the unit will focus on curating insofar as it involves art objects, it will also point to both historical instances of curation that did not involve art objects (eg. Wunderkammers) and present-day instances of curating where the term has become virtually synonymous with any act of selection (music, photographs, food). The overall aim of the unit is provide students with a working vocabulary so that they can ask critical questions of the contemporary practice of curation.</p>
<p>Lectures will largely provide a chronological history of curation, starting with early museums and collections, but with an emphasis on the rise of curating and the figure of the curator from the mid-1970s on. A number of key instances of curation (particular exhibitions and international Biennales and Triennials) will be selected for particular analysis. In this way, students will be given both an overall history of art curation and a way of thinking the term's almost infinite expansion in the present. The overall aim of the unit is to provide students with an appropriate working method for any curation they might undertake in the future and a way of thinking about issues of curation if they choose to work in a museum or write about art. In some ways, the unit is intended as a preliminary to the more practice-based unit Curating: Practice, although this is not its only possible outcome.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify the key theoretical questions involved in the practice of art curating;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a broad historical overview of the practice of curating;</li>
<li>Elaborate key moments in the history of curating and of prominent historical and contemporary curators;</li>
<li>Apply this knowledge to any practical act of curating they might undertake;</li>
<li>Engage with the issues and theories of curating insofar as it applies to their art practice or study of art history.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">CHM4221</span> - Chemistry honours coursework part-time B<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CHM4221">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-chemistry.html">School of Chemistry</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Grace">Assoc Professor Michael Grace</a>
<br/>

<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Grace">Assoc Professor Michael Grace</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CHM4221&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CHM4221">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in an approved Honours or Graduate Diploma in the discipline of chemistry</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>All students will undertake a Professional Studies topic and one core topic defined by the School, as well as three elective topics from specialised areas of chemistry, such as pericyclic reactions, separation science, advanced organic synthesis, main group inorganic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, computational chemistry and electron microscopy. Each topic will require students to attend 8 lecture equivalents making a total of 48 lecture equivalents for the unit. Further information is available from the course coordinator and at a meeting held with prospective students during second semester of third year.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Combination of examination and/or assignment (depending on the topic): 100% + Please consult the course coordinator about the assessment of individual topics.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/chemistry">Chemistry</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">SWK4560</span> - Supervised professional practice 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-SWK4560">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-social-work.html">Department of Social Work</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samone McCurdy">Dr Samone McCurdy</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maura Bevilacqua">Maura Bevilacqua</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=SWK4560&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=SWK4560&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-SWK4560">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK4060.html">SWK4060</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3400.html">SWK3400</a></span> and (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3180.html">SWK3180</a></span> or SWK3240)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in Bachelor of Social Work course codes 0004, 3426, 3864, 3870, 3964, 3965</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Supervised Professional Practice 2 enables students to observe, practice and critically reflect on the role of social work in a health or human services context and to further develop a professional social work identity.</p>
<p>The unit comprises a minimum of 500 hours of supervised field education.  Students are allocated to a suitable placement provider,  which may focus on direct practice;  community development; or social research, policy or project work.</p>
<p>Students are supported to integrate theoretical knowledge with practice skills and are supervised in the field by a qualified and experienced social work Field Educator and an allocated University Liaison Person.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply the AASW Code of Ethics to the practice context.</li>
<li>Identify the placement provider's legal and political context within the health and human services field.</li>
<li>Explain the legislation and social policies that influence the field of practice.</li>
<li>Articulate the theories and methods relevant to the placement context and critically reflect on their use and application.</li>
<li>Apply effective communication skills within the placement context.</li>
<li>Assume responsibility for self-learning and professional development while on placement.</li>
<li>Critically apply knowledge of assessment, intervention and referral skills to the field of practice.</li>
<li>Critically analyse different types of social research and their application to social work in the context of the placement setting.</li>
<li>Interpret and adapt knowledge of cultural diversity in order to work in a culturally responsive and inclusive manner in a social work context.

<p>Students must also provide evidence of completion of at least 500 hours of field placement.</p></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>14 x Weekly structured critical reflection (200 words each)</li>
<li>14 Completed records of supervision (100 words each)</li>
<li>Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Checklist (100 words)</li>
<li>Self-care plan (1,000 words)</li>
<li>Observed demonstration of communication skills (Part A) (20 minutes)</li>
<li>Mid-placement review report  (500 words)</li>
<li>Observed demonstration of communication skills (Part B - critical reflection) (10 minutes)</li>
<li>Personal professional practice framework (2,500 words)</li>
<li>Final placement review report (500 words)</li>
<li>Completed placement timesheet</li>
</ul>
<p>Mid-way through the placement, the allocated social work Field Educator and the student should review and assess the student's progress and performance against each of the nine key Learning Areas, using the rating guide provided in the Placement Workbook.  This forms the basis for the Mid-placement Report, which provides the student with formative feedback for the remainder of the placement.</p>
<p>Towards the end of the placement, the allocated social work Field Educator and the student should review and assess the student's progress and performance against each of the nine key Learning Areas, using the rating guide provided in the Placement Workbook.  This forms the basis for the Final Placement Report, which provides the student with summative feedback about their placement performance and a recommendation to the University for a pass or fail grade.</p>
<p>To meet AASW accreditation requirements and pass the unit, the student must reach a level of 'capable' (3) for all nine Learning Areas by the end of the placement.  This means the student is capable of practicing independently at the level expected of a newly qualifying practitioner.</p>
<p>The unit is pass grade only (PGO).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>The AASW set down the workload requirements for a Field Placement:</p>
<p>500 hours</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Social Work</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/socialwork/">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/socialwork/</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">MDC5010</span> - Advanced design communication<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MDC5010">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ian Wong">Mr Ian Wong</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ian Wong">Mr Ian Wong</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5010&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5010&amp;tpCode=S1-32&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester (extended)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MDC5010">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-suzhou.html">Suzhou</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester (extended) 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to F6005 (the double award Master of Industrial Design with SouthEast University, China).</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit develops the practice of advanced design communication by combining techniques and media, as well as experimental methods. Students will be required to examine current methods to help develop their design visualisation proficiency.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate advanced proficiency in the use of drawing as a means of communication to show salient features of an intended design;</li>
<li>Have an advanced practical and critical understanding of drawing as a method of externalising thoughts and developing ideas;</li>
<li>Communicate their ideas through concept presentation sketches and renderings;</li>
<li>Use drawing for persuasion and communication in a design context;</li>
<li>Demonstrate proficiency in a variety of techniques: traditional, electronic and experimental;</li>
<li>Select appropriate techniques to suit the nature of the design or the communicative purpose.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Block mode: 36 hours and 108 hours independent study; On campus: 4 hours and 8 hours of independent study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ARC1301</span> - Architecture communications 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ARC1301">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-architecture.html">Department of Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Laura Harper">Dr Laura Harper</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Laura Harper">Dr Laura Harper</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC1301&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ARC1301">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span>. Must be enrolled in one of the following courses: F2001, E3009, 3019, 3119, 4617, 4633</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Explores the principles, history and methods of perspective and orthographic projection, and engages in the practice of descriptive geometry through the use of contemporary computer technology and computer aided drafting (CAD). Basic techniques of visualisation and the translation of traditional analogue modes of representation into the digital will be introduced, along with technical CAD modelling and drawing skills in both two and three-dimensions.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Be aware of the function of computer aided drafting (CAD) as a fundamental tool of two and three-dimensional design;</li>
<li>Understand the transition between two-dimensional and three-dimensional systems of representation and their associated drawing conventions;</li>
<li>Have developed basic skills in computer aided drawing in two and three dimensions using industry standard hardware / software;</li>
<li>Understand the principles of descriptive geometry, its methods of representation and protocols of orthographic and axonometric projection;</li>
<li>Have basic knowledge of the theoretical and historical origins of perspective and orthographic projection as an analogue form of practice and representation;</li>
<li>Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 4 contact hours plus 8 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3115</span> - Indonesian 5: Indonesian political culture<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3115">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-indonesian-studies.html">Indonesian Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yacinta Kurniasih">Ms Yacinta Kurniasih</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yacinta Kurniasih">Ms Yacinta Kurniasih</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3115&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3115">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2114.html">ATS2114</a></span> or placement test or unit coordinator's permission</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2115</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit develops Indonesian cultural knowledge and language proficiency through a focus on Indonesian political culture. Passages from Indonesian online and print media and other texts are used to understand and critically analyse Indonesian political culture vis--vis Australian political culture as well as to understand how the relationship between the two comes to bear on Australian-Indonesian relations. Special attention is paid to how speakers and writers vary language styles (e.g. Indonesian, local language) to suit and persuade political and public audiences.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>analyse complex issues in Indonesian political culture;</li>
<li>critically read, assess and articulate an informed position - in the context of Indonesian political texts, as well as translate these positions across the Indonesian and English languages;</li>
<li>appraise the various styles of Indonesian language and distinguish how these are strategically used to influence audiences and public opinion;</li>
<li>use an expanded vocabulary set to listen to, speak/write in and read a range of Indonesian styles.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/indonesian-studies">Indonesian studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">
