<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">PHC5302</span> - Common problems in primary care<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-PHC5302">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-general-practice.html">Department of General Practice</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Eli Ristevski">Dr Eli Ristevski</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jan Coles">Professor Jan Coles</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=PHC5302&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-PHC5302">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>Students must NOT choose a topic previously competed in PHC5304 or PHC5303</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit has been created in collaboration with the Department of General Practice for students undertaking studies in ONE of the following five topics:</p>
<ul>
<li>Depressive and anxiety disorders in General Practice</li>
<li>Mindfulness-based stress management</li>
<li>Dermatology.</li>
</ul>
<p>Students undertaking this unit must choose only one topic. Each topic is equivalent to 6 credit points.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to;</p>
<p>Depressive and anxiety disorders in General Practice</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Interpret the principal psychiatric classification system currently in use, and apply it, in conjunction with appropriate clinical reasoning skills, to determine whether or not a patient has a depressive or anxiety disorder.</li>
<li>Determine the risk factors and underlying causes of depressive and anxiety disorders, and argue how these influence treatment.</li>
<li>Devise and implement a systematic approach to assessing the severity of different types of depressive and anxiety disorders, including their morbidity and mortality.</li>
<li>Devise and implement a systematic approach to the management of depressive and anxiety disorders, which includes a synthesis of the best available evidence, in addition to considering patient wishes and circumstances, community resources and the clinician's experience.</li>
<li>Distinguish between the presentations in General Practice of different types of depressive and anxiety disorders.</li>
<li>Devise a plan for future personal practice and professional development in the diagnosis and management of patients with depressive and anxiety disorders.

<p>Mindfulness-based stress management</p></li>
<li>Critically review the significant body of research linking psychological states like stress with a range of illnesses and lifestyle including disciplines within mind-body medicine such as neuroplasticity, psychoneuroimmunology and psychogenomics.</li>
<li>Critically review research demonstrating the benefits of psychological interventions like stress management and mindfulness</li>
<li>Practice the mindfulness meditation exercises in their various forms and critique their effectiveness.</li>
<li>Apply the principles of the mindfulness-based cognitive strategies and critique their effectiveness.</li>
<li>Critically reflect on their own experience of stress and ways in which they manage it.</li>
<li>Develop and implement mindfulness-based stress management in practice.</li>
<li>Demonstrate professional skills as a counsellor in mindfulness-based stress management.

<p>Women's sexual and reproductive health in General Practice (available Semester 2 2017)</p></li>
<li>Analyse the psychosocial context of women's lives and apply this analysis to women's sexual and reproductive health</li>
<li>Develop a systematic and evidence based approach to the diagnosis and management of women's sexual and reproductive health issues which commonly present in the General Practice setting</li>
<li>Evaluate those factors contributing to the prevalence of unplanned pregnancy and based on best available evidence formulate an appropriate response that addresses these issues in the General Practice setting</li>
<li>Develop a systematic and evidence based approach to contraceptive counselling and counselling for unplanned pregnancy and sexual problems</li>
<li>Critically appraise the evidence concerning hormone replacement therapy and screening for cervical, breast and ovarian cancer</li>
<li>Evaluate the health outcomes of violence against women and formulate appropriate responses in the General Practice setting based on best available practice evidence

<p>Child health (available Semester 1 2017)</p></li>
<li>Develop a systematic and evidence-based approach to the diagnosis and management of child health issues which commonly present in the Primary Health Care setting</li>
<li>Assess child development using valid and reliable assessment instruments, determine deviations from the norm and formulate appropriate management strategies in the Primary Health Care setting</li>
<li>Formulate a comprehensive management plan surrounding child health by collaborating with other health professionals</li>
<li>Analyse the psychosocial and environmental context of children's lives and apply this analysis to child health.</li>
<li>Identify paediatric emergencies which commonly present in the Primary Health Care setting and formulate an appropriate initial management plan</li>
<li>Effectively use the available literature to inform ongoing learning needs relating to child health

<p>Dermatology</p></li>
<li>Analyse how the structural components of the skin function in both healthy and diseased states</li>
<li>Demonstrate a systematic approach to generating and exploring an appropriate list of differential diagnoses, in a patient with a dermatological complaint</li>
<li>Deduce what further investigations, if any, are required, to aid diagnosis</li>
<li>Devise and implement a systematic approach to the management of dermatological disorders, which includes a synthesis of the best available evidence, patient wishes and circumstances, community resources and the clinician's experience</li>
<li>Devise a plan for future personal practice and professional development in the diagnosis and management of patients with dermatological conditions</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>See individual topic guides for details - some topics will require students to write up cases on patients they have seen in practice, to write up journals based on clinical activity and/or to perform audits on clinical activity</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Depressive and Anxiety Disorders in General Practice</p>
<ul>
<li>Case study - Depressive Disorder (2,500 words) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Case study - Anxiety Disorder (2,500 words) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical decision tasks (1 hour) (20%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirement:</p>
<p>Throughout this unit there are a number of activities (eg: discussion forums, individual wikis, group wikis, quizzes and virtual patients). Satisfactory participation in ALL of these activities is a requirement in order to progress through this unit.</p>
<p>Mindfulness-based stress management</p>
<p>Scientific stream:</p>
<ul>
<li>Clinical decision tasks (1,500 words) (25%)</li>
<li>Essay (1,500 words) (25%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Practical stream:</p>
<ul>
<li>Journal - personal (2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Journal - clinical (1,000 words) (20%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle: Throughout this unit there are a number of activities (eg: discussion forums, individual wikis, group wikis, quizzes and virtual patients).</p>
<p>Satisfactory participation in ALL of these activities is a requirement in order to progress through this unit.</p>
<p>Women's sexual and reproductive health in General Practice (available Semester 2 2017)</p>
<ul>
<li>Clinical decision task (case study 2,000 words) (25%)</li>
<li>Clinical research tasks (amounting to a total of 6,000 words) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical research task (audit of current practice in one of the areas of contraception, screening or menopause (2,000 words) (25%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Child health</p>
<ul>
<li>Case report (1,500 words) (20%)</li>
<li>Case scenario report (1,000 words) (10%)</li>
<li>Individual structured oral presentation (20 minutes) (30%)</li>
<li>Clinical decision tasks at the end of each module (up to 2,500 words in total) (10% for each module) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirement:</p>
<p>Throughout this unit there are a number of activities (eg: discussion forums, individual wikis, group wikis, quizzes and virtual patients).</p>
<p>Satisfactory participation in ALL of these activities is a requirement in order to progress through this unit.</p>
<p>Dermatology</p>
<ul>
<li>Pictorial case studies (1.5 hours) (25%)</li>
<li>Pictorial case studies (1.5 hours) (25%)</li>
<li>Case report (2,500 words) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirements:</p>
<p>Throughout this unit there are a number of activities (eg: discussion forums, individual wikis, group wikis, quizzes and virtual patients).</p>
<p>Satisfactory participation in ALL of these activities is a requirement in order to progress through this unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Equivalent of 12 hours a week in 6 credit point units run over 12 weeks</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/primary-health-care">Primary health care</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_law"><span class="unitcode">LAW4133</span> - International law seminar: International public order<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-LAW4133">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_law">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-law.html">Law</a></p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-LAW4133">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW4122.html">LAW4122</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>International public order is both the practical and the normative foundation of public international law. International law does not operate within a vacuum, nor does it consist of the pro forma application of abstract principles and universals detached from real world conditions. Rather, international public order is best understood as the practical regulation of a global society of state and sub-state actors, subordinate to the trans-national rule of law. International law, therefore, is inseparable from the wider issues of global governance, the mechanisms, institutions and principles that enable the global society to operate as an integrated political and legal system.</p>
<p>Taking this unit, students will not only acquire a sophisticated understanding of the concepts of international public order and the trans-national rule of law, but also how the integrity of the international system is inseparable from the practical operation of global governance. Understanding will be achieved through the detailed examination of a particular area of concern within international public order and how formal legal resolutions of disputes must necessarily be framed within terms of global governance and the trans-national rule of law.</p>
<p>The topics to be studied include: the international legal process (the concept and sources of international law); international law as the judicial basis of global governance; and practical problems in international law and world order (conflict prevention; socio-political justice; international economic law; and international environmental law).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will have acquired or developed:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>A deeper understanding of the principles and theories of public international law and international public order.</li>
<li>Experience in the practical application of these principles and theories to problem solving in contemporary issues and disputes within public international law.</li>
<li>Further development of the skills of legal research and writing as well as oral communication.</li>
<li>Greater understanding of the inter-relationship between public international law, global governance, international public order and international dispute resolution.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Research paper (4000 words): 50%; seminar presentation (written): 25%; seminar presentation (oral): 10%; and class attendance and participation: 15%.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MBA5228</span> - Global executive MBA transformation II<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MBA5228">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Butler">Professor Patrick Butler</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Butler">Professor Patrick Butler</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MBA5228&amp;tpCode=MBA-TP5-01&amp;tpYear=2019">MBA Teaching Period 5</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MBA5228">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>MBA Teaching Period 5 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5221.html">MBA5221</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5222.html">MBA5222</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5223.html">MBA5223</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5224.html">MBA5224</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5225.html">MBA5225</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5226.html">MBA5226</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MBA5227.html">MBA5227</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Global Executive MBA Transformation II unit comprises four component topics: Executive Leadership IV: Transformation Mindset, Corporate Governance, Executive Masterclass and Corporate Strategy.</p>
<p>For executives, leadership is inevitably about transformation and building sustainable organisations that are dynamic, adaptive and enduring despite turbulent and volatile business environments. Resilient executive leadership is based on an orientation where change and flux is the normal course of business, and Executive Leadership IV: Transformation Mindset will develop participants' ability to make sense of volatility, uncertainty and complexity. Constant change raises multiple ethical issues, and the development of participants' ethical acuity and judgement as leaders of successful transformation is central. In this unit participants will work towards their own personal leadership legacy commitment: the legacy that they commit to leaving as global, executive leaders.</p>
<p>Executive career development normally involves engagement with corporate affairs and boards of directors, and an understanding of policy, the regulatory environment and governance processes and relations becomes an important success factor. In Corporate Governance, the role, duties and powers of directors, managers and shareholders - and questions of good faith, care and diligence - are addressed.</p>
<p>Executive Masterclass comprises a series of seminars and workshops designed to provide opportunities to further customise the program for participants. Following earlier modules and units, including specialist modules at international business schools and experiential consulting projects in international markets, the opportunity exists in the Transformation Module to revisit and develop deeper insights into executive topics, and to open up any contemporary issues. Expert faculty and leading practitioners co-create content with program participants that reflects the developmental and experiential priorities of the class.</p>
<p>The long-term direction of an organisation, its competitive environment and scope of activities, and its mission, values, resources and competencies are all fundamental strategy questions for executives. Drawing on earlier studies of business models, business functions and experiential business consulting projects, Corporate Strategy is concerned with the overall scope of the organisation and how value is created in the various business units; the expectations of shareholders and the stock market are important drivers at this level. It serves to consolidate earlier learning, and cases, simulations, leaders' forums and engagement with industry experts and practitioners form the pedagogy.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals of this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>be able to analyse and synthesise complex business situations by drawing on the knowledge bases of Leadership, Corporate Governance, Executive Masterclass and Corporate Strategy</li>
<li>be able to demonstrate the ability to integrate and evaluate that knowledge to create and implement appropriate business initiatives and responses.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average six/eight hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">GEN3990</span> - Genetics in action research project<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-GEN3990">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biological-sciences.html">School of Biological Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matt McGee">Dr Matt McGee</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matt McGee">Dr Matt McGee</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=GEN3990&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=GEN3990&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-GEN3990">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students must have their proposed project and supervisor approved by the unit coordinator prior to enrolment. In addition, students must have at least a distinction average across 24 points of second level units, including a minimum of 12 points from <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS2011.html">BMS2011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS2042.html">BMS2042</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/GEN2041.html">GEN2041</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/GEN2052.html">GEN2052</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MCB2011.html">MCB2011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MCB2022.html">MCB2022</a></span>, MOL2011, or MOL2022.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>SCI3740, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SCI3990.html">SCI3990</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides the opportunity for high-achieving students to undertake an individual research project in Genetics with an academic supervisor. It includes a critical literature review, experimental design and data analysis. The student must maintain regular contact with supervisor(s) and subject coordinator.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Comprehend the fundamental process and requirements of scientific research;</li>
<li>Review and critically evaluate the scientific literature within a relevant discipline;</li>
<li>Demonstrate skills in experimental design, data collection and statistical analysis;</li>
<li>Interpret experimental results, and place the results in the broader context of the research discipline;</li>
<li>Communicate scientific findings and their implications, via oral presentations and written reports.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Oral presentation: 10%</p>
<p>Poster presentation: 15%</p>
<p>Written reports: 65%</p>
<p>Supervisor's assessment of project planning, conduct and development: 10%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Approximately 12 hours per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/ecology-and-conservation-biology">Ecology and conservation biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/genetics">Genetics</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/plant-sciences">Plant sciences</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/zoology">Zoology</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC2403</span> - Mechanics of materials<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC2403">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tuncay Alan">Dr Tuncay Alan</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chang Wei Sea">Dr Chang Wei Sea</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC2403&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC2403">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MAE2401.html">MAE2401</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit conveys the fundamental knowledge necessary for the analysis and design of mechanical engineering structures. It builds on aspects of applied forces and basic structural analysis that are contained in various units in level 1. It provides a focus for this prior learning with respect to the analysis of components and structures within a mechanical engineering context.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse the behaviour of structures under mechanical loads via free body diagrams.</li>
<li>Apply stress-strain relations in conjunction with elasticity and material properties.</li>
<li>Determine the mechanical stresses and structural deformations that arise within a body under applied loads.</li>
<li>Appraise complex solid mechanics problems and use knowledge and skills to develop simplified models and generate accurate solutions.</li>
<li>Apply structural analysis theory to predict performance and reliability of structures under a combination of different loadings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours of lectures, 3 hours of practice sessions and 6 hours of private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2171</span> - Korean introductory 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2171">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-korean-studies.html">Korean Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andy Jackson">Associate Professor Andy Jackson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andy Jackson">Associate Professor Andy Jackson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2171&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2171">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1171.html">ATS1171</a></span></p>
<p>Students enrolled in Arts courses are prohibited from taking this unit. In addition, students enrolled in this unit are prohibited from taking <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1171.html">ATS1171</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is designed for students with no or little knowledge of the Korean language to build a foundation in their basic knowledge of the Korean language and culture. Students will be introduced to contemporary Korean, with special emphasis on spoken usage for everyday situations. Students will also be introduced to a general overview and understanding of modern Korean history, culture and society.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completing this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Participate in simple social conversations in Korean</li>
<li>Use basic 'survival' Korean for traveling in Korea</li>
<li>Communicate basic information about themselves and family members</li>
<li>Read and write simple Korean</li>
<li>Demonstrate a basic understanding of Korean culture and society, through theoretical frameworks</li>
<li>Develop a critical awareness of various issues arising in the globalised world, including rapid changes in current and future work places</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RTS5102</span> - Radiation therapy science 5<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RTS5102">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Caroline Wright">A. Prof Caroline Wright</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Caroline Wright">A. Prof Caroline Wright</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Catherine Kealley">Dr Catherine Kealley</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RTS5102&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RTS5102">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS4101.html">RTS4101</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS4102.html">RTS4102</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS4103.html">RTS4103</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS5110.html">RTS5110</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS5101.html">RTS5101</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RTS5103.html">RTS5103</a></span>.Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 3889, M6004</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit covers advanced medical radiations physics with a specific focus on image formation and instrumentation. Students will gain an in-depth conceptual understanding of the instrumentation used for each of the diagnostic imaging modalities. Students will undertake a critical review of the physical properties responsible for image formation. Students will acquire an appreciation of the Image Registration process and the importance of combination imaging in radiation therapy. Students will gain an in-depth knowledge in the underlying theory and corresponding advancements in clinical radiation therapy instrumentation. Students will apply this knowledge in a critical review of advanced radiation therapy techniques.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Illustrate the principles of operation and image formation of CT, PET, MRI and Ultrasound modalities reflecting on their use in radiation therapy;</li>
<li>Discuss Image Registration and evaluate the advantages gained from combination imaging;</li>
<li>Describe the scientific concepts and analyse the clinical applications of Intensity-Modulated Radiotherapy;</li>
<li>Evaluate the principles of  Image-Guided Radiotherapy, describing the instrumentation and equipment used;</li>
<li>Appraise the advanced techniques of radiation therapy including Stereotactic Radiosurgery and Brachytherapy.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Scientific poster with narration and audio (20%),</li>
<li>Presentation (20 minutes) (20%),</li>
<li>Critical review (1,000 words) (10%),</li>
<li>Written invigilated examination (2 hours) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle Requirement: To pass this unit, students must:</p>
<ul>
<li>Achieve a combined mark of 50% or more of the available marks for the Scientific Poster, Presentation and Critical Review assessments.</li>
<li>Achieve 50% or more of the available marks for the written examination.</li>
<li>Students must pass the exam to pass the unit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/radiation-therapy">Radiation therapy</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT3153</span> - Research-based learning<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">18 points, SCA Band 2, 0.375 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT3153">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stephen Huxford">Mr Stephen Huxford</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT3153&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT3153">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2083.html">FIT2083</a></span> or FIT2084</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students participate full time in a research and development placement over a 22-week period. Students are required to apply their knowledge, skills, professional attitudes and ethical behaviour in a research context. They develop their communication, time management, self-reflection and teamwork skills, experience a professional research and development environment and obtain feedback from supervisors on their performance.</p>
<p>Students will be supervised by a supervisor and will be visited by the CE or academic nominees.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>participate as an interested, active member of a possibly multi-disciplinary research team;</li>
<li>design, organise and conduct innovative information technology research projects;</li>
<li>communicate research findings orally and in writing;</li>
<li>demonstrate ethical behaviour, professional practice and initiative in research;</li>
<li>critically analyse and assess information technology literature.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are deployed full-time for 22 weeks in a research and development placement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MID3110</span> - Professional midwifery practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MID3110">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Gayle McLelland">Dr Gayle McLelland</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Gayle McLelland">Dr Gayle McLelland</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MID3110&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MID3110">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MID3000.html">MID3000</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides students with a comprehensive and clinically meaningful final preparation for transition to practice as a competent beginning level midwife. The unit provides students with the opportunity to explore in detail a range of midwifery and medically led models of care and the midwifery leadership necessary to promote the profession, providing childbearing women with choice in the care they receive. Students are provided with the opportunity to explore contemporary midwifery practice, regulatory and professional issues and identify evidence informed midwifery practices.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Reflect critically upon the role that women-centred care and  midwifery led models of care play in the Australian maternity care context;</li>
<li>Appraise contemporary and evidence-based midwifery practice;</li>
<li>Discuss challenges of autonomous practice and midwifery leadership;</li>
<li>Demonstrate skill in ethical decision making in the  identification of appropriate solutions to complex midwifery issues;</li>
<li>Demonstrate proficiency in the implementation of planned midwifery care; and</li>
<li>Demonstrate midwifery competency based on the ANMC National Competency Standards for the Midwife.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Clinical placement: 160 hours.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Essay (3,000 words) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Case study (3,000 words) (60%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical placement with clinical assessment (160 hours) (Pass / Fail)</li>
<li>Clinical portfolio with all minimum requirements completed (Pass / Fail)</li>
</ul>
<p>Students must pass the clinical assessment to pass the unit. Students must submit the clinical portfolio for audit in order to be course completed.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>This is a flexible unit with a number of compulsory on campus workshops.</p>
<p>One four hour orientation session and three four hour compulsory on-campus workshops: 16 hours</p>
<p>Self-directed learning: 60 hours</p>
<p>Clinical placement: 160 hours</p>
<p>Total: 316 hours.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing-and-midwifery">Nursing and midwifery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ADA4500</span> - Design thinking approaches<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ADA4500">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ilya Fridman">Dr Ilya Fridman</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ilya Fridman">Dr Ilya Fridman</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADA4500&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADA4500&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADA4500&amp;tpCode=T2-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 2</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADA4500&amp;tpCode=T4-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 4</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ADA4500">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Term 2 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Term 4 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li><li>Term 2 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li><li>Term 4 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>For students enrolled in Master of Design program: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4500.html">MDC4500</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4550.html">MDC4550</a></span>;</p>
<p>For students enrolled in non-cognate courses: Nil</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ADA1111.html">ADA1111</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ADA3111.html">ADA3111</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is developed to introduce non-cognate students in Masters courses to Design Thinking, and to its application within a wide range of problems and situations. These skills and strategies include a range of conceptual and communication approaches, ways to investigate and reconsider the context in which we work and live, as well as potential for innovation.  Design Thinking brings together some approaches that are known in the sciences and humanities, such as analysis and synthesis, but applies them in ways that are particular to a design approach.  Design Thinking can enable a more flexible approach to problems, and a more nuanced engagement with the complex issues of our contemporary world. This unit will introduce students to the key skills and practices associated with Design Thinking, and offer opportunities to explore the application of these basic creativity techniques. The course is delivered partly on-line, with lectures and workshops offering key activities supporting students' learning.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate understanding of the concepts of Design Thinking and their application;</li>
<li>Identify and analyse ill-defined, real-world project problems and relevant Design Thinking approaches;</li>
<li>Apply Design Thinking methods and approaches to a project-based problem, to develop new perspectives on key issues and to identify potential opportunities;</li>
<li>Develop, test and evaluate original proposals in response to project-based problems;</li>
<li>Develop an awareness of their preferred approaches to complex tasks, and ways these may be extended through Design Thinking.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including an average of 3 contact hours (in person or online) plus 9 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>

<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUT1101</span> - Science foundations<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUT1101">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chiara Murgia">Dr Chiara Murgia</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Aimee Dordevic">Dr Aimee Dordevic</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUT1101&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUT1101">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1001.html">NUT1001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1010.html">NUT1010</a></span>. Must be enrolled in Bachelor of Nutrition Science or Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics (Honours).</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on developing fundamental scientific knowledge as the basis for nutrition science. This unit introduces you to the chemistry of organic molecules expanding to incorporate the biochemical pathways relevant to nutrient metabolism.</p>
<p>Protein, fat, carbohydrate and alcohol metabolism are covered in detail laying the foundation for a detailed understanding of energy metabolism in humans.</p>
<p>The unit concludes with the introduction of other molecules of life (DNA and RNA) and describes the processes of genetic inheritance, mitosis, meiosis and gene transcription and the importance of gene nutrient interactions in human health.  Student centered teaching and learning methods will be used to support the delivery of the unit content.</p>
<p>Students' participation as adult learners will be encouraged through the curricula with emphasis on the development of basic scientific communication skills.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate foundation knowledge of basic sciences to include chemistry, molecular biology, and biochemistry relevant to human nutrition and dietetics</li>
<li>Describe the chemistry of atoms and molecules</li>
<li>Explain how atoms and molecules interact in chemical reactions and calculate chemical equations (stoichiometry)</li>
<li>Describe the chemical and biochemical aspects of biological molecules</li>
<li>Classify the main features of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells (including membranes, organelles and enzymes), and correlate their structures with biological functions</li>
<li>Explain the aspects of cellular macronutrient and alcohol metabolism in terms of dietary input and energy release.</li>
<li>Explain mechanisms of genetic inheritance and the factors that govern the flow of information from DNA to RNA to protein</li>
<li>Demonstrate basic knowledge and skill in laboratory experimentation and in the reporting and collation of experimental data</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>5 x laboratory practicals (500 words each) (20%)</li>
<li>Scientific poster - group presentation (10%)</li>
<li>Mid Semester Examination (20%)</li>
<li>Final examination (3 hours) (50%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>11 hours contact per week plus 13 hours self directed study.</p>
<p>3 x 2 hours lectures, 1 x 2 hours tutorial and 1 x 3 hours practical.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nutrition">Nutrition</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC2404</span> - Mechanics of fluids<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC2404">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Isaac Pinar">Dr Isaac Pinar</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Citsabehsan Devendran">Dr Citsabehsan Devendran</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kenny Tan Boon Thong">Assoc Professor Kenny Tan Boon Thong</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC2404&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC2404&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC2404">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>24 credit points</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MAE2404.html">MAE2404</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CHE2161.html">CHE2161</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit develops the students' physical understanding of fluid statics and fluid flow and the interaction of fluid forces with solids.</p>
<p>Topics include hydrostatics, Reynolds transport theorem, continuity and momentum equations, control volume analysis, the Bernoulli equation, viscous pipe flow,  pumps, dimensional analysis, boundary layers, flow measurement techniques and applications of fluid forces in flow - lift and drag.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse fluid forces acting on bodies exposed to a volume of static fluid, with extension to fluid undergoing rigid body motion.</li>
<li>Determine solutions to flow problems, with simplifications as appropriate, using a control volume approach to transport of mass and momentum.</li>
<li>Apply dimensional analysis and modelling to plan experiments, present results meaningfully and predict prototype performance.</li>
<li>Determine lift and drag forces on bodies (including motor vehicles) subjected to fluid motion, describing the effects of boundary layer modification and flow separation.</li>
<li>Determine flow rates and pressure drops in pipe networks under steady state conditions for either laminar or turbulent flows.</li>
<li>Select suitable pumps for a range of pipe networks and/or flow conditions and describe typical properties of turbo-machines.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 50%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component (assignments, tests, mid-semester exams, laboratory reports) and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit.  Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 3 hours of laboratory/problem solving classes  and 6 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/mechatronics-engineering">Mechatronics Engineering</a></p>
<p>Renewable Energy Engineering</p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR5004</span> - Contemporary nursing practice 4<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR5004">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Scott">Mr Chris Scott</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Scott">Mr Chris Scott</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5004&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5004&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR5004">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5002.html">NUR5002</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5003.html">NUR5003</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5011.html">NUR5011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5022.html">NUR5022</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5033.html">NUR5033</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR5111.html">NUR5111</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 3966, M6016</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides final preparation of the student for practice as a registered nurse. Adult learning principles are applied to encourage the student to identify specific learning needs and pursue opportunities to achieve tailored educational objectives. The approach to clinical learning featured in this unit enables students to explore an area of specific interest in nursing.</p>
<p>A five week clinical consolidation placement is also included in this unit that will assist students in preparation for professional practice.</p>
<p>The increasing importance of professional portfolios for the purpose of maintaining and demonstrating competency will be emphasized in this unit.</p>
<p>A focus on principles of clinical leadership, therapeutic and professional communication, multidisciplinary team work, and clinical decision making will enable consolidation and application of prior learning in this course facilitating the transition from student to professional nurse.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the principles of clinical management for patients with advanced cardiac and respiratory illness.</li>
<li>Reflect on and identify specific learning needs in preparation for registration as a professional nurse;</li>
<li>Utilise adult learning theories, concepts and principles to identify specific learning needs and strategies by which these can be met;</li>
<li>Apply effective decision making frameworks to the identification and management of practice based problems and issues;</li>
<li>Develop and implement patient centred care interventions that encompass patients' cultural, ethical and developmental needs;</li>
<li>Reflect critically on personal and professional development in preparation for practice as a registered nurse;</li>
<li>Demonstrate readiness for beginning practice in accordance with, Nursing &amp; Midwifery Board of Australia Registered Nurse Standards for Practice, Code of Ethics and Code of Professional Conduct for Nurses, and;</li>
<li>Develop evidence of competency through the development of a professional portfolio.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Clinical placement: 200 hours.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Learning contract (2000 words) (20%)</li>
<li>Clinical performance (200 hours) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Pre-clinical laboratory sessions - compulsory 100% attendance</li>
<li>Must complete clinical placement (240 hours)</li>
<li>Conference presentation (15%)</li>
<li>Professional portfolio (3500 words) (25%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>8 hours a week: 4 hours lectures, 4 hours tutorials over 8 weeks. In addition, students will be required to undertake 200 hours of clinical placement.</p>
<p>Please note: Students who undertake this unit in the summer semester will be on campus for 5.5 weeks intensive mode.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p>Nursing and midwifery</p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3191</span> - Media analytics lab<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3191">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>

<br/>
</p>

<br/>
</p>

<ul>

</li>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3191">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2186.html">ATS2186</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2187.html">ATS2187</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2188.html">ATS2188</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in Bachelor of Media Communication.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit is a core unit for the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html">Bachelor of Media Communication</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Media Communication (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html">https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The Media Analytics Lab is a multi-disciplinary learning environment where students from the different specialisations in the Bachelor of Media Communication come together to explore new concepts, skills and practices in media analytics such as infographics, data journalism, data mining, digital ethnography, and audience research. Students will devise an analytics research project that can test the capabilities of new technologies and explore applications. The lab fosters creativity and experimentation in media production while also developing professional skills in collaboration and adaptability.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify and discuss the communicative and creative role of media analytics in contemporary media environments and business contexts;</li>
<li>display proficiency in a variety of media analytical skills and practices;</li>
<li>work reflectively, independently and collaboratively with peers to conceptualise and design a media analytics project;</li>
<li>apply skills to a media production/project that critically reflects on the evolving technologies and practices of media analytics.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html">Bachelor of Media Communication</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Media Communication (<a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html">http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2002.html</a>)</span></p>
<p><a href="../aos/digital-humanities">Digital humanities</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">
